    {

      "timestamp": "[00:00-00:01]",
      "transcript": "That's a great question.",

    },
    {
      "speaker": "Galit Mayaan-Lustig",
      "timestamp": "[00:01-00:03]",
      "transcript": "Okay, let me chime in a little bit on this.",
      "speaking duration": 2,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 100.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "None",
      "interuption": "No",

      "screenshare": "No",
      "screenshare_content": "None"
    },
    {
      "speaker": "Jeff Thompson",
      "timestamp": "[00:03-00:25]",
      "transcript": "There is also um so there's subsets of endocrine cells in the gut that are known to form sort of synapse like structures with sensory afference. And there's at least one publication that shows that uh luminal derived antigens, so they were using like fluorescent dextrins are taken up by those specific endocrine cells.",
      "speaking duration": 22,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "None",
      "interuption": "No",
      "overlap": "Yes",
      "screenshare": "No",
      "screenshare_content": "None"
    },
    {
      "speaker": "Galit Mayaan-Lustig",
      "timestamp": "[00:25-00:25]",
      "transcript": "Mhm.",
      "speaking duration": 0,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "None",
      "interuption": "No",
      "overlap": "Yes",
      "screenshare": "No",
      "screenshare_content": "None"
    },
    {
      "speaker": "Jeff Thompson",
      "timestamp": "[00:27-00:43]",
      "transcript": "So there's possibility that some of these endocrine cells are are sampling at least antigen, maybe whole bacteria from from the lumen and that there's signaling happening between those endocrine cells and then either sensory neurons but uh or or other enteric neurons that are there in the gut.",
      "speaking duration": 16,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "None",
      "interuption": "No",
      "overlap": "No",
      "screenshare": "No",
      "screenshare_content": "None"
    },
    {
      "speaker": "Galit Mayaan-Lustig",
      "timestamp": "[00:43-00:53]",
      "transcript": "Okay. And once such detection occurs assuming that it's a whole life bacteria that is that is being detected, can it then travel to the brain?",
      "speaking duration": 10,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "Open Palms",
      "interuption": "No",
      "overlap": "No",
      "screenshare": "No",
      "screenshare_content": "None"
    },
    {
      "speaker": "Jeff Thompson",
      "timestamp": "[00:53-00:53]",
      "transcript": "So.",
      "speaking duration": 0,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "None",
      "interuption": "No",
      "overlap": "No",
      "screenshare": "No",
      "screenshare_content": "None"
    },
    {
      "speaker": "Galit Mayaan-Lustig",
      "timestamp": "[00:53-00:57]",
      "transcript": "To the CNS or it will die in the process.",
      "speaking duration": 4,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 100.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "None",
      "interuption": "No",
      "overlap": "No",
      "screenshare": "No",
      "screenshare_content": "None"
    },
    {
      "speaker": "Jeff Thompson",
      "timestamp": "[00:57-01:25]",
      "transcript": "Um all right, so what's published is just antigen. Uh my lab has some unpublished data showing that live bacteria can be taken up by those cells and that they can survive for at least 48 hours in a really small amount. But we haven't done any transfer experiments. So there's no there's no evidence to my knowledge of gut bacteria being viable and trafficking via these anatomical pathways to the brain.",
      "speaking duration": 28,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "None",
      "interuption": "No",
      "overlap": "No",
      "screenshare": "No",
      "screenshare_content": "None"
    },
    {
      "speaker": "Jeff Thompson",
      "timestamp": "[01:25-01:53]",
      "transcript": "But I do think there's some experimental data at least from the oral or nasal microbiome showing that bacteria that are present at those epithelial surfaces uh can traffic across the the barrier and into the the brain and can actually be viable and live there. So it's not coming from the gut um but it's another microbiome surface uh that that can directly at least shows as an example that that that bacteria can can do this.",
      "speaking duration": 28,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "Open Palms",
      "interuption": "No",
      "overlap": "No",
      "screenshare": "No",
      "screenshare_content": "None"
    },
    {
      "speaker": "Galit Mayaan-Lustig",
      "timestamp": "[01:53-02:03]",
      "transcript": "Okay. And and uh Michael, you mentioned that TLRs are expressed on in the ENS, are other innate receptors also expressed?",
      "speaking duration": 10,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "None",
      "interuption": "No",
      "overlap": "No",
      "screenshare": "No",
      "screenshare_content": "None"
    },
    {
      "speaker": "Michael Coleman-Hicks",
      "timestamp": "[02:03-03:45]",
      "transcript": "Uh yeah, so so first and foremost I was going to say um so the idea of a of a of a microbe, you know, traveling um through through a cell or living in a cell is, you know, we know this in in viruses obviously, right? So that's kind of a cool thought that it is possible but you know, no one's ever shown it. So I think that's also a really cool idea potentially um for for a a grant idea. That's kind of far out there. But anyways, um the other yeah, so I was actually talking about this yesterday uh with a couple people that if you because we've done this taking out different um um sensory neuron populations and done some some sequencing and we see um depending on the disease state or pathological state that your sensory neurons can look like, you know, neurons or they can have signatures that look like immune cells and have upregulation of of a wide variety of different receptors that are typically um uh immune in in nature. We call it like topic immune expression. And then there's some there's this is already out um that in a high fat diet or during obesity the the neurons look like fat cells um where they're um have more leptin and they respond to more more more like um um metabolic um signatures in the gut. So yeah, and the cool thing about these sensory neurons in the periphery is that they they can they can do this because they're, you know, they're outside of the blood brain barrier and they're able to be influenced by the by stimulus outside stimuli outside of the the brain. So some interesting stuff.",
      "speaking duration": 102,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "Open Palms",
      "interuption": "No",
      "overlap": "No",
      "screenshare": "No",
      "screenshare_content": "None"
    },
    {
      "speaker": "Laura Eisen",
      "timestamp": "[03:45-04:18]",
      "transcript": "The TLRs are expressed on many types of cells in the brain too, neurons, gleal cells, microgleal cells and other astrocytes in the brain that also express many of the same cytokines that are expressed by immune cells. So I think you know, that's one of the interesting things. There's a great deal of blurring between the nervous system and the immune system in in many different compartments in the body.",
      "speaking duration": 33,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "None",
      "interuption": "No",
      "overlap": "No",
      "screenshare": "No",
      "screenshare_content": "None"
    },
    {
      "speaker": "Laura Eisen",
      "timestamp": "[04:18-04:19]",
      "transcript": "And that changes over time.",
      "speaking duration": 1,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "None",
      "interuption": "No",

      "speaking duration": 1,

      "transcript": "So.",
      "speaking duration": 1,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,

      "speaking duration": 0,

    {
      "speaker": "Jane Ya-Hui Tseng",
      "timestamp": "[04:21-04:41]",
      "transcript": "I wonder uh if people have a look our you know sequenced in the brain tissue, what kind of uh you know bacteria, virus they they found whether they related to any, you know, gut or oral.",
      "speaking duration": 20,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,

    {
      "speaker": "Xiaoqiu Wang",
      "timestamp": "[04:48-05:01]",
      "transcript": "They've I think they've found herpes virus pretty that's the kind of the latest um uh buzz in the literature, but bacteria as well.",
      "speaking duration": 13,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,

    },
    {
      "speaker": "Xiaoqiu Wang",
      "timestamp": "[05:01-05:14]",
      "transcript": "So I I wanted to ask where kind of Michael's been talking about the peripheral neuroinflammation as one mechanism of triggering neurodegenerative disease.",
      "speaking duration": 13,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,

    },
    {
      "speaker": "Xiaoqiu Wang",
      "timestamp": "[05:14-05:31]",
      "transcript": "Um what about like systemic dissemination of actual microbes? Um I guess that uh mechanism would be different, right? So you know, treponema for example, getting into the bloodstream and getting to the brain and um.",
      "speaking duration": 17,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,

    {
      "speaker": "Xiaoqiu Wang",
      "timestamp": "[05:31-05:40]",
      "transcript": "So what would that when when it hits the brain, what would that neuroinflammation process look like?",
      "speaking duration": 9,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "None",

      "screenshare_content": "None"
    },
    {
      "speaker": "Jeff Thompson",
      "timestamp": "[05:49-06:01]",
      "transcript": "I think that's a really cool question because I do think that's an outstanding gap in the field. We know for a lot of these age related neurodegenerative disorders that peripheral inflammation.",
      "speaking duration": 12,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,

      "speaking duration": 0,

      "timestamp": "[06:08-06:10]",
      "transcript": "What what my question was about that was just um.",
      "speaking duration": 2,

      "smile_other": 0.0,

    {
      "speaker": "Michael Coleman-Hicks",
      "timestamp": "[06:10-06:24]",
      "transcript": "When you when you're looking for Ecola, how are you how are you how I guess are you looking for it um in the brain and you know, do you perfuse the brains and and how does it all work? I'm curious to know how yeah, that's interesting.",
      "speaking duration": 14,
      "nods_others": 0,

      "smile_other": 0.0,

      "speaking duration": 1,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,

    {
      "speaker": "Robert Bryan Jr.",

      "speaking duration": 0,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,

    },
    {
      "speaker": "Robert Bryan Jr.",
      "timestamp": "[06:26-06:27]",
      "transcript": "That I've been very interested in.",
      "speaking duration": 1,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,

    {
      "speaker": "Robert Bryan Jr.",
      "timestamp": "[06:27-06:30]",
      "transcript": "And I just want to tell you about an experiment we did unpublished.",
      "speaking duration": 3,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,

      "speaker": "Robert Bryan Jr.",
      "timestamp": "[06:30-06:31]",
      "transcript": "We took a a",
      "speaking duration": 1,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "None",

      "timestamp": "[06:31-06:31]",

      "speaking duration": 0,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "None",

    },
    {
      "speaker": "Robert Bryan Jr.",
      "timestamp": "[06:31-06:32]",
      "transcript": "And in a in a control.",
      "speaking duration": 1,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "None",
      "interuption": "No",
      "overlap": "No",
      "screenshare": "No",
      "screenshare_content": "None"
    },
    {
      "speaker": "Robert Bryan Jr.",
      "timestamp": "[06:32-06:41]",
      "transcript": "And we gavaged a a fluorescent labeled Ecola this fact it's antibiotic resistant into the parents to be of these mice.",
      "speaking duration": 9,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "None",
      "interuption": "No",
      "overlap": "No",

      "screenshare_content": "None"
    },
    {
      "speaker": "Robert Bryan Jr.",
      "timestamp": "[06:41-06:54]",
      "transcript": "And we let them grow up for 15 weeks and we could find this Ecola uh throughout the body including the brain.",
      "speaking duration": 13,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0.0,
      "smile_other": 0.0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "None",
      "interuption": "No",
      "overlap": "No",
      "screenshare": "No",
      "screenshare_content": "None"
    },
    {
      "speaker": "Robert Bryan Jr.",
      "timestamp": "[06:54-06:57]",
